name: Words Derived from Falconry Terms Quiz | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: This word meaning "deceived" comes from a common practice for calming falcons.
questions.explanation:
Hoodwinked.

	Falcons are calmed by placing hoods over their heads, to block out upsetting sights and make the falcon think it is night. To slip a hood over a wild, agitated falcon was to "hoodwink" the bird,

questions.text: A possible derivation of this word for "old man" involved someone who carried falcons' perches into the field.
questions.explanation:
Codger.

	One claim for the history of this word is that it's a variation of "cadger," the person who carried a falcon's perch- which was known as a "cadge"- into the field. As the story goes, this duty was reserved for retired falconers who could not perform more strenuous tasks. Another derivation, a bit more far-fetched, is that the cadger was unpaid and had to beg for tips- thus leading to the word "cadge" as a synonym for "beg."

questions.text: This phrase, meaning "finished with due to frustration," originated from the fact that a falcon who has just eaten is not interested in hunting.
questions.explanation:
Fed up.

	A "fed up" falcon would refuse to fly and wanted nothing to do with hunting.

questions.text: This word, meaning "young and inexperienced," was also used as a term for a young hawk.
questions.explanation:
Callow.

	"Callow" derives from a word meaning "bare," much as newborn falcons are covered with only a bit of wispy down.

questions.text: This word meaning "looking thin and worn" comes from the appearance of a wild-caught hawk.
questions.explanation:
Haggard.

	A haggard was a female hawk caught during migration, who would often be thin and tired from her journey.

questions.text: This word for "alcoholic beverage" derived from a word used to describe a falcon's drinking.
questions.explanation:
Booze.

	"Booze" comes from "bouse" or "bowse," a word originally used to describe the drinking behavior of birds of prey, especially when they drank (water, of course!) to excess.

questions.text: This word meaning "overeat" may have derived from observations of falcons.
questions.explanation:
Gorge.

	"Gorge" also means "throat," and is often used to refer to the throats of birds (the feathers on a bird's throat, for example, are known as a "gorget.") Because of their extendable crop, falcons can eat a large meal at once, and they do not chew their food!

questions.text: This word for "an adult accompanying a minor" may have derived from the French word for a hood used to cover a falcon's head.
questions.explanation:
Chaperone & chaperon.

	The French term meant "little cape" and is related to the word for hat- chapeau.

questions.text: This word for "to excite" comes from a word for when a hawk ruffles and shakes its feathers.
questions.explanation:
Rouse.

	When a hawk awakens, it will rouse.

questions.text: Which model of Toyota was named after a male falcon?
questions.explanation:
Tercel.

	A tercel or tiercel originally referred to a three-year-old male falcon, but is now used as a generic term for a male falcon.
